awd_titl_txt: Uranium isotopes and past changes in Southern Ocean circulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Ocean circulation has deep connections with processes around the Earth including the melting or growing of continental ice sheets. The exact mechanisms linking ocean circulation to ice sheet variability can be difficult to tease out using modern observations alone. Geologists therefore look to the past for examples of when ocean circulation changed and how those changes relate to other phenomena in past eras. In particular, it has been found that the circulation of Antarctic Bottom Water, dense water that sinks around the Antarctic continent and fills the deepest parts of the world?'s ocean, may have a very intimate link with melting of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. The concentration of naturally-occurring uranium in Southern Ocean sediments, formed under low oxygen conditions, is a key tool that has been applied to reconstruct past circulation changes during one past warm period, ~125,000 years ago, in one area of the Southern Ocean.  This project will apply this recently developed method to other areas of the Southern Ocean and to other time periods in the past (up to 500,000 years ago) in order to investigate a more robust mechanism for how circulation around Antarctica is linked to ice sheet melting and how this might change in the future.  The project supports an early-career researcher as well the training of a graduate and undergraduate students in the research.  Outreach will be accomplished through the development of a new course and with high school students through events such as the Ocean Sciences Bowl competition. The project will contribute to infrastructure by developing a new proxy for paleoceanography, which has the potential to better constrain models of ice sheet melting and inform on issues related to climate change and sea level rise.

To more accurately reconstruct past deep Southern Ocean oxygenation conditions, and therefore Antarctic Bottom Water (AABW) circulation, the project will utilize a novel geochemical approach using the isotope composition of authigenic uranium (U-234/U-238), augmented by other redox sensitive metals (Re and Mn). This combination of measurements allows for periods of changing oxidation to be identified that elemental proxies alone could not detect. This approach will be applied in multiple Southern Ocean cores to test for reproducibility and sensitivity to varying sedimentary environments. Furthermore, the project will investigate multiple interglacial periods over the past 500,000 years to examine the response of AABW across a range of forcings and Antarctic Ice sheet extents. The result will be a robust perspective on AABW variability during interglacial periods and its relationship to external forcings (orbital configuration, CO2, Southern Ocean productivity) and West Antarctic Ice Sheet melting.

por.por_cntn:
The Southern Ocean surrounding Antarctica is a critical part of Earth's climate system because the way the ocean circulates there can influence the balance of heat and greenhouse gases around the globe. In this project, we set out to investigate how Southern Ocean circulation may have changed over 5 ice age cycles that have occurred over the past half million years. We used a sediment record from the Ocean Drilling Program that was retrieved from the deep South Atlantic (Site ODP-1094). Our proxy measurement for circulation changes was the enrichment of naturally-occurring uranium in the sediments, which tends to occur at low oxygen conditions. Part of our work was also to critically evaluate potential pitfalls of this proxy. A more sluggish circulation rate would tend to reduce oxygenation at our core site and therefore enrich uranium in the sediments. We focused on two potential pitfalls: (1) that low oxygen in the sediments can also be caused by an influx of organic matter that settles down from the water column during times of high biological productivity; and (2) once uranium is enriched under low oxygen conditions, there is a possibility that when oxidizing conditions return, some of the previously enriched uranium could dissolve and return to the seawater or move and become enriched in another part of the core.

First regarding the influence of organic matter influx, we did in fact find that there are very large increases in organic matter delivery to the sediments at each of the transitions between ice ages and warm climate periods at our site. In all five of these so-called glacial terminations, there is some enrichment of uranium. In these cases, the termination-centered uranium peaks cannot be used to directly infer circulation changes by themselves. In contrast, in 2 of the past warm periods (when climate was similar to today), there are additional peaks in uranium when organic matter delivery to the core was either steady or decreasing. In these cases, the uranium peaks must be due to the slow-down of Southern Ocean circulation delivery oxygen to our site. These two events, one which occurred about 127,000 years ago and an older event which occurred 400,000 years ago, are potentially a result of melting events of Antarctic ice interfering with the formation of the dense water around the continent that drives Southern Ocean circulation. This has important implications for possible scenarios in projecting future change.

We found further results regarding the second potential pitfall mentioned above, that enriched uranium in the core may have later dissolved or moved in the core. To assess this possibility, we looked at some other metals that become enriched or dissolved under different oxygenation conditions (specifically, rhenium and manganese) as well as the isotopic composition (U-234/U-238 ratio) of the uranium.  The rhenium and manganese results show consistent changes in oxygenation across the glacial termination and subsequent warm period circulation slow down identified by the uranium record around 400,000 years ago. This gives confidence that there were relatively few changes in the enriched uranium record after it was deposited. The uranium isotope results have been more intriguing. We expected to have the uranium isotope ratio reflect the isotope composition of seawater, since this is the source of enriched uranium in the sediments. In some parts of the core, the isotope ratios can be predicted by this simple model; however, in particular during the glacial termination uranium peaks, the isotope ratio was actually found higher than what is found in seawater, meaning it cannot be explained by our assumed sources of uranium. This work has led us to a hypothesis that perhaps a small amount of the daughter isotope in the uranium decay chain (U-234) can diffuse within the core after enough time has occurred to produce the daughter from its parent (U-238). This apparently can cause an anomaly in the uranium isotopic composition without significantly changing the bulk uranium record, especially with the corroboration of the rhenium and manganese results. Further work to fully explain the uranium isotopic results is a thesis chapter currently being written by a PhD student that has worked on the project.  

In summary, in this project we discovered new geochemical events that can be used to reconstruct climate-relevant changes in the Southern Ocean over the recent ice age cycles. We trained 2 graduate students and 1 undergraduate student, shared our findings with the scientific community that led to several collaborations, and interacted with the public at events like the local Ocean Sciences Bowl, hosted by our institution.
